docs.lead_paragraph: The public option had to go. For Senate Democratic leaders struggling to round up 60 votes for their sweeping health care legislation, that was one loud message from centrist holdouts, including Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, who on Friday night gave the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, the handshake of a lifetime in committing his support.

headline.main: Things That Changed, And Stayed the Same
headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Changes that have been made to sweeping health care legislation, including dropping of government-run health insurance plan that liberals favored as way to create competition for private insurers, described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The public option had to go.      For Senate Democratic leaders struggling to round up 60 votes for their sweeping health care legislation, that was one loud message from centrist holdouts, including Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, who on...

docs.lead_paragraph: When no other Republican was willing to work with Democrats on legislation to revamp the health care system, Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine stuck it out. So of the 40 Republicans expected to vote against the bill, Ms. Snowe's ''no'' is the one that might give supporters of the measure pause. Ms. Snowe was part of the bipartisan Group of Six on the Senate Finance Committee that worked for months to draft the health care bill. And even when the other two Republicans in the group, Senators Michael B. Enzi of Wyoming and Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, gave up, Ms. Snowe kept at it.
docs.abstract: Sen Olympic Snowe, Republican of Maine, in formal statement that in some ways confirms obvious, decides she will vote against ending debate on health insurance bill and oppose it; has complained repeatedly in recent days that Democrats are rushing bill and have set artificial deadline of completing it by Christmas (S)
docs.snippet: When no other Republican was willing to work with Democrats on legislation to revamp the health care system, Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine stuck it out. So of the 40 Republicans expected to vote against the bill, Ms. Snowe's ''no'' is the one...

docs.lead_paragraph: Nasty charges of bribery. Senators cut off midspeech. Accusations of politics put over patriotism. Talk of double-crosses. A nonagenarian forced to the floor after midnight for multiple procedural votes. In the heart of the holiday season, Senate Republicans and Democrats are at one another's throats as the health care overhaul reaches its climactic votes. A year that began with hopes of new post-partisanship has indeed produced change: Things have gotten worse.

headline.main: In the Senate, Ill Effects From a Debate About Health

docs.abstract: Enmity and acrimony are rising between Senate Republicans and Democats as debate continues over health care reform legislation in heart of holiday season; while Democrats appear to have 60 votes needed to push through legislation, Republicans say they intend to force series of six procedural showdowns that would keep Senate in session through Christmas Eve; photos (M)

docs.abstract: Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, will vote against the health care legislation. But her questions and criticisms of the bill are particularly problematic for Democrats given how hard she worked on the health care measure this year and how badly she would like to vote for it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Killing the idea of a government-run health insurance plan was crucial for Senate Democrats trying to round up 60 votes for their legislation. But dropping it from the bill makes no difference in the number of people expected to gain health benefits, the Congressional Budget Office says.

headline.main: No Change in Coverage Numbers in Dropping of Public Option

docs.lead_paragraph: The term “Christmas tree” has its own meaning on Capitol Hill. It usually refers to a bill decorated with “ornaments,” or special goodies for the folks back home.
